results.title: Olaf Ruhen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch, author Olaf Ruhen recalls a life travelling throughout Australia and the South Pacific gathering materials for his books. He speaks of his love of the sea and his affinity with the Tongan people. Ruhen recalls his friendship with the painter, Albert Namatjira. A visit to a writers’ conference in New York inspired Ruhen to create a forum for Australian authors, the Australian Society of Authors.

results.title: Evictions
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Richard Lowenstein
results.brief_description: Documentary/drama on police-enforced evictions in Melbourne during the 1930’s depression and the tactics the organised unemployed used at the time to combat the situation. Based on the memories of Noel Counihan and Tom Hills and adapted from the book ‘Weevils in the flour’ by Wendy Lowenstein, the film combines interviews with period reconstruction. Erwin Rado Award for Best Australian Short Fiction, Melbourne Film Festival, 1980.

results.title: Don't really know how I feel about this movie...
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @cinerobz's Tik Tok
results.brief_description: Is Blonde, a fictionalised look at Marilyn Monroe’s life by Melbourne director Andrew Dominik, honouring or exploiting the star’s legacy? Reviews are divided, but Iconic images from Monroe’s life and work, along with the film’s recreation of many of these moments are being used on social media to both damn and praise the film, ensuring Monroe’s complex role in pop culture conitnues to resonate.
results.title_for_label: Don’t really know how I feel about this movie…
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Is Blonde, a fictionalised look at Marilyn Monroe’s life by Melbourne director Andrew Dominik (Chopper, The Assassination of Jesse James), honouring or exploiting the star’s legacy? Reviews are divided, but Iconic images from Monroe’s life and work, along with the film’s recreation of many of these moments are being used on social media to both damn and praise the film, ensuring Monroe’s complex role in pop culture continues to resonate. By remixing scenes from the film, social video makers can at least salvage the visually striking elements of the film to focus on the cinematography and Ana de Armas’ performance, yet continued recycling of Monroe’s image creates a chasm between person and her persona, removing agency in favour of the ongoing perpetuation of a myth.

Instead of obsessing only over Monroe’s image, other social media accounts have shared facts and information about the icon that defy the ‘blonde bombshell’ archetype. Diet Prada created a tiled post titled ‘More than her trauma’, using the popular online listicle style of article to celebrate Monroe’s trailblazing activism against Hollywood sexism, fight for equal pay, support for LGBTQIA+ rights and philanthropy.
description_for_label: Is Blonde, a fictionalised look at Marilyn Monroe’s life by Melbourne director Andrew Dominik, honouring or exploiting the star’s legacy? Reviews are divided, but Iconic images from Monroe’s life and work, along with the film’s recreation of these moments are being used on social media to damn and praise the film, ensuring Monroe’s complex role in pop culture continues to resonate.

results.title: Heartbreak High’s inclusiveness goes global
results.brief_description: In this video, LGBTIQA+ flags are overlayed on Heartbreak High characters to signal their sexual identities. With over 1M views, it speaks to the popularity of the show but also the importance of representation on TV. Until the 1990s, it was uncommon to find queer characters on screen, so audiences had to do things like search for subtext or create fanfiction. Heartbreak High’s sexually (and culturally) diverse characters reflect contemporary society and the evolution of screen representation, while easy-to-use video and social media tools let fans create shareable content that celebrates diversity and connects like-minded people around the world.
results.description:

With over 1M views, it speaks to the show’s popularity but also the importance of screen representation. Until the 1990s, queer screen characters were uncommon, so audiences had to search for subtext or create fanfiction. Heartbreak High’s sexually (and culturally) diverse characters reflect our society and the evolution of screen representation, while easy-to-use video tools let fans create shareable content that celebrates diversity and strengthens community.

results.title: Hyper >> [games magazine] Issue 1, December 1993
results.creator_credit: Otter Publishing, Stuart Clarke and Phillip Keir
results.brief_description:
Hyper was a multi-platform Australian video game magazine. It was Australia’s longest running gaming magazine, published from 1993 to 2019.

In addition to coverage of current major video game systems and game releases, Hyper also covered anime, DVD movies, arcade and classic games, and featured interviews with industry professionals and articles on game-related content such as game classifications, computer hardware and video game music. Hyper also had a sister magazine, the PC gaming oriented PC PowerPlay. (citation from Wikipedia).

A digital version of the magazine can be found here: https://archive.org/details/hyper-001_20200724_0134/mode/2up

results.title: Tractor goth girl
results.brief_description: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.
description_for_label: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description: During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life.

constellations_primary.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_primary.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Read more

More than 200 kung fu films later, Jason Phu had his own movie to make by Kerrie O’Brien

My parents met at the fish market by Jason Phu in The Lifted Brow

Interview #34 — Jason Phu by Sophia Cai in Liminal

Storytelling with Jason Phu by Sabina McKenna in Acclaim

Who is Jason Phu? by Jane Albert in Broadsheet

results.title: VFX in Peter Rabbit
results.credit_line:
PR1: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™, the Movie ©2018 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
PR2: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™ 2:The Runaway, the Movie ©2021 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
results.brief_description: A look at how acclaimed VFX studio Animal Logic bought Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit to life.

constellations_primary.name: VFX to fantasy and freedom
constellations_primary.description: Founded in Sydney, and now with offices worldwide, Animal Logic are an Academy Award-winning VFX and animation studio whose job is to bring the impossible to life. And they're in good company with these other artists and filmmakers.

results.description: First springing from the mind of Beatrix Potter, Peter Rabbit is a creature that has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the beloved character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live action and animation for Peter Rabbit (2018), they used prop rabbits during the shoot so cast members had a tangible property to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
description_for_label: Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live-action and animation for Peter Rabbit, they used prop rabbits during the shoot for cast members to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.

PETER RABBIT™ & © FW&Co. PETER RABBIT™ Movie © 2021 CPII All Rights Reserved

Special thanks to Columbia Pictures
